response.answer: Autophagy is required for exercise-induced mitochondrial biogenesis in this mouse swimming model. The study showed that swimming training increased autophagic flux in skeletal muscle (ju_2016, ju_2016__abstract__000) and that exercise-induced increases in mitochondrial biogenesis markers (SDH, COX IV, PGC-1α) were abolished when autophagy/mitophagy was inhibited with colchicine (ju_2016, ju_2016__abstract__000; ju_2016, ju_2016__results__002). The authors conclude mitophagy and mitochondrial biogenesis are tightly coupled and that a coordinated balance between these processes is a prerequisite for mitochondrial adaptation to endurance exercise (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__003). Mechanistic data in the paper note an exercise-related increase in the mitophagy receptor Bnip3 while PINK1/Parkin protein levels were unchanged, suggesting Bnip3 may mediate the mitophagy signal during exercise in this model (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__002; ju_2016, ju_2016__results__001). Overall, the authors state basal autophagy plays an important role in mitochondrial biogenesis/homeostasis during skeletal muscle adaptation to endurance exercise training (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__004).

citations.relevant_quote: The autophagic flux assay demonstrated that swimming training resulted in an increase in the autophagic flux (*100 % increase in LC3-II) in mouse skeletal muscle.

The endurance exercise training induced increases in mitochondrial biogenesis marker proteins, SDH, COX IV, and a mitochondrial biogenesis promoting factor, PGC-1a but this effect was abolished in colchicine-treated mouse skeletal muscle.

This assay demonstrated that increased mitochondrial biogenesis markers were observed when autophagy was activated by exercise training, while exercise training-induced mitochondrial biogenesis was abolished when mitophagy was inhibited with colchicine treatment (Fig. 5).

The findings from the present study support the notion that mitophagy and mitochondrial biogenesis are tightly coupled and the coordinated balance between these two processes is a prerequisite for mitochondrial adaptation [38].
In contrast, swimming exercise training increased Bnip3 protein concentration further with colchicine treatment in the present study.
The present study showed that the protein levels of PINK1 and Parkin were unchanged by exercise training as well as colchicine treatment.
Our findings highlight the important role of basal autophagy in mitochondrial biogenesis/homeostasis during skeletal muscle adaptation to endurance exercise training.

response.evidence_quality: Direct experimental evidence from the cited mouse swimming training study using short-term colchicine inhibition of autophagy and biochemical markers.
caveats: Evidence and conclusions are drawn from the mouse swimming exercise model with short-term colchicine treatment as reported in the cited study; applicability to other species, exercise modalities, or chronic inhibition was not provided in the supplied text.

response.answer: Studies of Blue Zones attribute longevity primarily to lifestyle factors such as low smoking prevalence, ample physical activity, favorable nutrition, and strong social bonds (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__001). response.answer:
In human dietary and exercise interventions the review reports changes in (1) DNA methylation at specific genes and global marks, (2) circulating microRNA (miRNA) expression, and (3) histone modifications as a measured epigenetic category. Examples from intervention studies include: 

- DNA methylation (gene-specific and global): methylation changes were observed in glycemia-related loci (e.g., TXNIP, LINE-1, LUMA) (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__001; nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__010), lipid-related loci (e.g., CPT1A, BMAL1, ADRB3, LINE-1) (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__003; nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__010), blood-pressure–related loci (e.g., LINC00319, ACOT13, KCNV1, NR3C1, RBM9, CDYL, GATA4, TBPL2) (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__005; nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__010), inflammatory genes (e.g., TNF, IL6, FCER2, DUSP10, BCL2, CD6, CRP) after exercise or dietary programs (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__006; nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__010), and adipokine-related genes (e.g., RNF39, COL4A1, CD36, CD14, FADS1, PDK4) (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__007; nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__010). Specific intervention examples include TNF and IL6 DNAm changes after 8 weeks of eccentric resistance training (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__006) and decreases in ADRB3 DNAm after folate plus hazelnut-oil supplementation (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__006). 

- Circulating miRNAs: many miRNAs changed with diet and/or exercise and correlated with metabolic outcomes. The review lists miRNAs associated with glycemic responses (e.g., miR-99b, miR-128-1-5p, miR-374a-5p, miR-221-3p, miR-21, miR-106b, let-7c, miR-17, miR-296, miR-20b, miR-92a, miR-93, miR-186, miR-192, miR-342, miR-374b, miR-22, miR-145, miR-126, miR-29a, miR-28-3p, miR-150, miR-34a, miR-210) (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__010; nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__001; nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__003). Example: larger decreases in serum miR-99b were associated with lower fasting glucose after an 18-month hypocaloric diet plus physical activity intervention (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__001). Other miRNA changes reported include miR-100/miR-99a decreases with reduced ectopic fat after lifestyle change (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__004) and miR-21/miR-222 decreases associated with antioxidant changes after MitoQuinol plus exercise (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__007). 

- Histone modifications: histone acetylation/methylation are named among the main epigenetic signatures analyzed in interventions, although the review emphasizes DNA methylation and miRNAs in the intervention examples (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__000; nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__010). 

Overall the review summarizes multiple human trials showing diet- and exercise-associated changes in DNAm at specific genes and in circulating miRNA profiles; those epigenetic marks have been reported to correlate with glycemic, lipid, blood-pressure, inflammatory/oxidative stress, and adipokine outcomes (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__010; nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__000).

response.answer:
Summary — mechanisms
(f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__000) (nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__results__001)

- Intermittent fasting (IF) / periodic fasting: IF engages many of the same nutrient‑sensing pathways as CR but in a cyclic manner. The fasting–feeding cycles can produce pronounced improvements in insulin sensitivity and promote stress‑response programs (e.g., sirtuins, heat‑shock responses) and autophagy, so some benefits overlap with CR while the temporal patterning alters pathway activation. (nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__results__001) (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__002)

Mechanistically they mimic fasting‑induced reductions in anabolic signalling and induction of protective programs. (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__003)

Summary — evidence for longevity/healthspan benefits
- Preclinical (model organisms): CR is the most reproducible dietary intervention extending healthspan/lifespan across organisms; IF and periodic fasting also can increase lifespan in models and can do so even without large overall calorie reduction. (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__abstract__000) (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__002) (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__003)

- Humans and translational evidence: Human trial data show feasibility and some health benefits from CR (e.g., CALERIE reported metabolic and inflammatory improvements), but there is no clear, consistent evidence that bona fide CR increases human lifespan; results are heterogeneous and affected by genetic background, sex, study design, and other variables. Study variability complicates interpretation. (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__001) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__014) (nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__results__002)

Practical interpretation
(nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__results__000) (nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__results__001)

Variability in study designs, participant characteristics, and dietary protocols complicates the interpretation and generalizability of findings.

response.evidence_quality: Preclinical evidence is strong and consistent (CR; supportive for IF and FMD). Human evidence is limited, heterogeneous, and not definitive for lifespan extension.
caveats: Human longevity data are lacking or mixed; many mechanistic and clinical inferences derive from model organisms and short‑ to mid‑term human trials.
Study heterogeneity (designs, populations, diet protocols) limits direct comparison and generalizability.

response.answer:
Summary — areas of agreement
- Both works present structured frameworks to classify and evaluate aging biomarkers and emphasize the need for rigorous validation and standardized evaluation (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__000; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__009). (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__000) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__009)

- Both prioritize mechanistic relevance: biomarkers should reflect underlying biology or pathways that drive aging rather than merely correlate with age (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008). (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008)

- Both require validation across contexts (e.g., tissues, species, cohorts) and call for longitudinal human cohort validation before routine use (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008). (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008)

- Both recognize specific assay-level validation needs (analytical and clinical validation) and discuss regulatory/surrogate-endpoint implications if biomarkers predict clinical benefit (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__009; cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001). (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__009) (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001)

- Both note promise in molecular/multi-omics approaches (e.g., epigenetic clocks, proteomic clocks, plasma proteomics) while recognizing current limitations (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006). (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006)

Key differences / emphasis
- Emphasis on physiological biomarkers: Furrer & Handschin explicitly argue that physiological (functional) biomarkers are "ready for prime time" and are strong, established predictors of morbidity and mortality, recommending them as benchmarks (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__010; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__009). (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__010) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__009)
  By contrast, the Cell framework (Moqri et al.) places more emphasis on creating a consensus terminology and evaluation pathway for molecular biomarkers and on advancing molecular biomarkers (including epigenetic and proteomic) toward regulatory uses and surrogate endpoints, while acknowledging the complementary role of vitality/resilience and functional measures (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__000; cell_2023, cell_2023__conclusion__000; cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001). (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__000) (cell_2023, cell_2023__conclusion__000) (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001)

- Skepticism vs. pragmatic development: Furrer & Handschin express stronger caution about current molecular clocks — noting lack of consensus, variable predictive value, tissue specificity, circadian and technical variability, and substantial replicate deviations — and argue for careful benchmarking against physiological measures (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__007; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008). (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__007) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008)
  Moqri et al. (Cell) are forward-looking about deploying validated molecular biomarkers in trials and regulatory settings, and note that some candidate methylation-based biomarkers and omics-derived biomarkers have already shown predictive, prognostic, or response properties, while still calling for further cross-cohort validation (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001; cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002). (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001) (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002)

- Framing of generalizability: both include generalizability as a criterion, but Furrer & Handschin list practical constraints (costs, invasiveness, applicability across demographics) explicitly in their framework, elevating these implementation factors as assessment axes (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__009). (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__009)
  Moqri et al. discuss generalizability in terms of cross-tissue and cross-species utility and emphasize cohort/validation needs and regulatory use cases (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002; cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001). (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002) (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001)

Practical intersection: both recommend (explicitly or implicitly) that molecular biomarkers be benchmarked against meaningful physiological/clinical outcomes (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__009) and that molecular clocks be validated longitudinally in humans before routine use (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008; cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001). Overall takeaway
- The two frameworks are largely aligned on principles (mechanistic relevance, analytical/clinical validation, generalizability, and cohort validation), but differ in emphasis: Furrer & Handschin stress that physiological/functional biomarkers are presently most robust and should serve as benchmarks, and they are more skeptical about current molecular clocks; Moqri et al. (Cell) focus on building consensus frameworks, advancing selected molecular biomarkers (including epigenetic and proteomic clocks) toward regulatory and trial use, and on standardizing terminology and validation paths so molecular biomarkers can fulfil those roles. response.answer:
Across the corpus the most commonly acknowledged methodological limitations in human longevity research are:

- Limited translatability from model organisms to humans (physiological differences and laboratory artifacts). (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__003)

- Very long timeframes and high resource requirements for human longitudinal trials. (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__005)

- Lack of consensus and high variability among molecular “aging” biomarkers (epigenetic, transcriptomic, proteomic clocks) and technical variability between replicates. (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006)

- Small cohort sizes and high measurement noise (especially for transcriptomic clocks), limiting validation. (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006)

- Ethical and regulatory constraints because aging is not recognized as a disease, forcing trials in "healthy" individuals under strict standards. (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__introduction__002)

- Confounding environmental, socioeconomic, and recordkeeping issues (e.g., Blue Zones, childhood postcode effects) that complicate causal inference. (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__001) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__002)

- Potential antagonistic interactions between candidate geroprotective drugs and established lifestyle interventions (notably exercise), complicating interpretation and clinical application. (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__004)

These limitations are repeatedly noted in the text and are cited above.

Most of these clocks, however, have only been tested in small cohorts and are marred by inherently large transcriptional noise
treatment and trials would by definition be performed in 'healthy' individuals, with very high regulatory and ethical standards.

response.answer: Barry et al. (2014) reported that they searched PubMed, EBSCOhost and ProQuest using keywords about cardiorespiratory fitness, BMI and mortality for the period January 1980–May 2013. They specified inclusion criteria (prospective design; all-cause mortality outcome; CRF assessed by maximal or VO2peak test; BMI directly measured; CRF and BMI jointly assessed; normal-weight-fit as reference). For ProQuest they sorted results by relevance and examined the first 300 items. They also screened reference lists, contacted specific authors for additional data, excluded three articles for reasons explained, and retained 10 articles for the meta-analysis.

response.answer: The corpus does not recommend any pharmaceutical drugs for reliably extending human lifespan. It states that “no evidence for efficacy (and safety) for the application of any of these pharmacological and interventional factors on the human aging process exists” (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__007). The papers list many candidate compounds that have been proposed or tested in model organisms — examples include resveratrol, curcumin, astaxanthin, epigallocatechin‑gallate, Protandim, melatonin, spermidine, methylene blue, nicotinamide riboside and nicotinamide mononucleotide (NAD+ precursors), metformin, acarbose, 17α‑estradiol, canagliflozin, senolytics such as fisetin, dasatinib and quercetin, rapamycin/rapalogs, berberine, curcumin, antioxidants (vitamins C and E), and others — but the reviews emphasize that none have been successfully validated as anti‑aging therapies in humans (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__005; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006). Rapamycin is noted as one of the few compounds with reproducible lifespan/healthspan effects in multiple model organisms, yet clinical trials on rapamycin for human longevity have not been performed (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__005; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__007).

Short-Duration Swimming Exercise after Myocardial Infarction Attenuates Cardiac Dysfunction and Regulates Mitochondrial Quality Control in Aged Mice.

response.answer:
Summary: In the mouse exercise model reported here, autophagy/mitophagy is required for the exercise-induced increase in mitochondrial biogenesis: endurance (swimming) training increased autophagic flux, and when autophagy/mitophagy was pharmacologically blocked the exercise-induced upregulation of mitochondrial biogenesis markers was abolished. Genetic autophagy deficiency likewise produced abnormal mitochondria and reduced mitochondrial function, supporting a necessary role for autophagy in the biogenic response. The authors therefore conclude that mitophagy and mitochondrial biogenesis are tightly coupled during skeletal muscle adaptation to endurance exercise; Bnip3 (rather than PINK1/Parkin) is suggested as a candidate mitophagy mediator in this setting.

Key supporting points:
(ju_2016, ju_2016__abstract__000)
- The endurance training–induced increases in mitochondrial biogenesis markers (SDH, COX IV, PGC-1α) were abolished when autophagy/mitophagy was inhibited with colchicine. (ju_2016, ju_2016__abstract__000) (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__002)
- Short-term inhibition of autophagy was sufficient to reverse/abolish the effects of 8 weeks of exercise training, indicating a rapid dependence of biogenesis on ongoing autophagy. (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__002)
- Autophagy-deficient transgenic mice showed accumulated protein aggregates, abnormal mitochondria, and decreased mitochondrial function in skeletal muscle, consistent with autophagy being important for mitochondrial quality and for exercise-induced mitochondrial adaptations. (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__003)
- The authors state that mitophagy and mitochondrial biogenesis are tightly coupled and that a coordinated balance between them is a prerequisite for mitochondrial adaptation to exercise. (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__003)
- Bnip3 protein was increased in exercised muscle (with colchicine treatment) while PINK1/Parkin were unchanged, leading the authors to highlight Bnip3 as a possible mediator of exercise-induced mitophagy. (ju_2016, ju_2016__abstract__000) (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__001)

Overall interpretation: The provided study provides multiple lines of in vivo mouse evidence (exercise-induced increase in autophagic flux; pharmacologic inhibition that abolishes biogenesis markers; and corroborating transgenic-model data) that autophagy/mitophagy is necessary for, and tightly linked to, exercise-induced mitochondrial biogenesis in skeletal muscle. The study also points to Bnip3 as a candidate receptor mediating selective mitophagy in this context.

citations.relevant_quote: swimming training resulted in an increase in the autophagic flux (*100 % increase in LC3-II) in mouse skeletal muscle.

The endurance exercise training induced increases in mitochondrial biogenesis marker proteins, SDH, COX IV, and a mitochondrial biogenesis promoting factor, PGC-1a but this effect was abolished in colchicine-treated mouse skeletal muscle.

increased mitochondrial biogenesis markers were observed when autophagy was activated by exercise training, while exercise training-induced mitochondrial biogenesis was abolished when mitophagy was inhibited with colchicine treatment
short-term inhibition of autophagy is sufficient to reverse/abolish the effects of 8 weeks of exercise training
These transgenic mice showed accumulated protein aggregates, abnormal mitochondria, and decreased mitochondrial function in skeletal muscle.
mitophagy and mitochondrial biogenesis are tightly coupled and the coordinated balance between these two processes is a prerequisite for mitochondrial adaptation
The present study showed that the protein levels of PINK1 and Parkin were unchanged by exercise training as well as colchicine treatment.
A mitochondrial receptor, Bnip3, was further increased in exercised muscle when treated with colchicine

response.evidence_quality: Direct in vivo experimental evidence from the cited mouse exercise study (swimming training with pharmacologic autophagy inhibition and referenced autophagy-deficient transgenic models).
caveats: The study used short-term pharmacologic inhibition (colchicine) to block autophagy; mechanistic details (e.g., upstream kinases/phosphatases for Bnip3) are not defined in this report: "Currently, kinases and phosphatases for Bnip3 are not known [35] and more studies need to be done to elucidate the precise roles of Bnip3 in mitophagy regulation in response to exercise." (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__002)

response.answer: Long-term aerobic (endurance) exercise preserves muscle mass and function during aging through several, overlapping mechanisms. 1) Maintains mitochondrial quantity and quality: endurance exercise increases PGC-1α expression driving mitochondrial biogenesis and helps preserve mitochondrial function in older active individuals (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__005; s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__introduction__002). 2) Enhances mitochondrial proteostasis and mitophagy: upregulation of mitophagy and mitochondrial protein turnover is linked to improved mitochondrial quality and, in animal models, to muscle hypertrophy in aged mice (s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__introduction__003; cells_2022, cells_2022__body__005). 3) Shifts muscle signaling toward growth and away from wasting: exercise reduces myostatin levels, promotes anabolic signaling (Akt–mTOR), and can reduce proteolytic ubiquitin ligases associated with atrophy (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__006). 4) Improves perfusion and fiber characteristics: endurance training induces angiogenesis (expansion of capillary networks) and fiber-type adaptations that support muscle function and nutrient/gas delivery (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__007). 5) Improves metabolic support for muscle: muscle contraction during exercise increases insulin sensitivity and glucose uptake, supporting energetic demands and muscle maintenance (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__007). Collectively, these adaptations are consistent with observations that lifelong aerobic training preserves muscle mass and function with age (s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__introduction__000).

response.answer:
Key lifestyle factors linked to longevity in Blue Zones reported in the provided sources are:

- Low smoking prevalence (fewer people who smoke) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__001).
- Ample physical activity / “natural movement” (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__001; nutrients_2025, nutrients_2025__methods__000).

response.answer:
Brief summary
- Moqri et al. (Cell 2023) present a consensus framework focused on defining terminology, classifying biomarkers (predictive/prognostic/response/surrogate), and establishing evaluation and validation steps to advance biomarkers for use in longevity interventions. They emphasize distinguishing biomarkers of biological age versus biomarkers of the rate of aging (AgeDev and pace), the need for analytical and clinical validation, and caution about data-driven models that may mix causal and noncausal features (see citations). (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__000; cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002; cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001; cell_2023, cell_2023__results__001).

- Furrer & Handschin (Physiol Rev 2025) provide a framework that stresses rigorous validation (including biological, cross-species, predictive, analytical, and clinical validation), strong standardization, and the central role of physiological (functional) biomarkers — arguing these should serve as benchmarks for molecular clocks and that multicomponent/systemic indices are currently most promising. They also caution that molecular clocks must be used with care until longitudinal validation is available (see citations). (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__009; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__010).

Where they agree
- Need for a formal framework and validation pathway. Both works call for standardized frameworks and multiple validation steps (analytical and clinical) to move biomarkers toward clinical use (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__000; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008).
- Mechanistic/biological plausibility matters. Both emphasize that biomarkers should reflect underlying biology (not just correlates) and that mechanistic evidence strengthens a biomarker (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008).
- Caution about data-driven molecular clocks and need for longitudinal validation. Moqri et al. warn that data-driven algorithms may mix causal and noncausal features, and Furrer & Handschin state molecular clocks must be used with caution pending validation in longitudinal human studies (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__001; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008).
- Value of integrative/multisystem measures. Both recognize that composite or multisystem biomarkers can be more robust than single-feature measures (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__001; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008).

Where they differ (emphasis and recommendations)
- Emphasis on physiological/functional biomarkers: Furrer & Handschin place physiological biomarkers (e.g., cardiorespiratory fitness, muscle mass/strength, frailty measures) at the center, stating they are "ready for prime time" and should benchmark molecular measures, and arguing multicomponent functional indices may currently be best for monitoring aging (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__010; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__009; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008). Moqri et al. support including functional parameters in model training but present a broader regulatory/terminology framework rather than prioritizing physiologic measures as the primary benchmark (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__002; cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__000).
- Conceptual framing of age measurement: Moqri et al. articulate and formalize the distinction between biomarkers of the progress of aging (biological age / AgeDev) and biomarkers of the rate of aging (pace/speedometer), proposing AgeDev as terminology and recommending paired evaluation of both kinds of biomarkers (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002; cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__002). Furrer & Handschin focus more on validation dimensions and on whether biomarkers reflect pathways that drive aging, with less explicit adoption of the AgeDev/pace terminology in the excerpts provided (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008).
- Cross-species and biological-driver validation emphasis: Furrer & Handschin explicitly list cross-species validation and whether biomarkers derive from pathways that actively drive aging as key criteria, and they argue these validations increase a biomarker’s likelihood of reflecting fundamental aging processes (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008). Moqri et al. also discuss mechanistic criteria and generalizability, including between species and tissues, but their excerpts place more explicit emphasis on regulatory use cases and surrogate endpoint validation pathways (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002; cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001).

Synthesis / practical implication from the two frameworks
- The two frameworks are complementary: Moqri et al. provide a regulatory/terminology structure and formal distinctions (AgeDev vs pace) useful for study design and surrogate-endpoint thinking, while Furrer & Handschin emphasize the immediate practical value of physiological, multicomponent biomarkers and rigorous multi-dimensional validation (including cross-species and biological-driver validation) as benchmarks for molecular approaches. Combining these perspectives suggests prioritizing robust physiological endpoints as anchors while pursuing mechanistically informed, well-validated molecular clocks that report both biological age and the pace of aging.

response.answer:
Summary — mechanisms
- Caloric restriction (CR): across model organisms CR is the most reproducible dietary intervention for extending healthy lifespan and acts largely by down-regulating nutrient-sensing growth pathways (insulin/IGF signalling and TOR), activating energy sensors and autophagy (AMPK activation, mTORC1 inhibition, increased autophagy). (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__abstract__000) (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__000) (nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__results__000).

(nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__results__001) (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__002).

(f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__003).

Evidence for longevity/healthspan benefits — what the studies show
- Model organisms: CR is the best‑documented and most reproducible intervention extending healthspan/lifespan from yeast through rodents and primates. (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__abstract__000) (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__000).

- Fasting/periodic approaches: both intermittent and periodic fasting have extended lifespan in experimental models and can do so even with little or no net calorie reduction. (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__002).

- Fasting-mimicking diets: reported to induce fasting-like biomarkers (lower glucose/IGF‑1, higher ketones) and to produce tissue-repair and healthspan effects in studies cited. (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__003).

- Humans and translational gaps: controlled human trials show CR is feasible and improves cardiometabolic and inflammatory markers, but CR has adverse signals (e.g., reduced bone mineral density) and primate studies are conflicting (one program found no lifespan benefit, another found lifespan and healthspan benefits). There is currently no clear evidence that bona fide CR increases human longevity. Study heterogeneity, genetic and sex differences, and protocol variability complicate translation. (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__001) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__014) (nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__results__002).

response.answer:
Across the provided review, the most commonly acknowledged methodological limitations in human longevity research are:

- Limited translatability from model organisms: many interventions and mechanistic findings in canonical models "might therefore not be directly extrapolatable to humans" (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__003) and this is explicitly noted as a general constraint on the field (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__abstract__000).

- Artifacts of laboratory conditions and physiological differences in models: tightly standardized housing (pathogen-reduced, controlled temperature not at thermoneutrality, fixed light cycles, sedentary animals) can create nonrepresentative results (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__003).

- Long duration, cost, and regulatory/ethical hurdles for human trials: "the long time frame that is needed based on human life expectancy" complicates trials, and aging "is not recognized as a disease by regulatory agencies," increasing regulatory complexity (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__005).

- Lack of consensus, validation, and technical variability in molecular biomarkers (clocks): "no consensus on methodology and clock as standard biomarker for human aging has emerged," many clocks were tested in small cohorts and show large transcriptional/noise and replicate variability (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006).

- Measurement confounders and practical limits of -omics approaches: plasma proteome signatures "can be affected by organ function," metabolomics has unknowns and noise, and some proteomic approaches remain costly (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006).

- Population heterogeneity and socioeconomic/environmental confounding: lifelong socioeconomic factors (e.g., "the childhood postcode") and access disparities strongly influence outcomes and can confound interpretation (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__002).

- Complexity of interventions and interactions with lifestyle: single pharmacological compounds are unlikely to match multifactorial lifestyle effects and can antagonize proven interventions such as exercise (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__004).

- Safety gaps and absence of human efficacy data for some proposed therapies: several interventions (e.g., telomerase gene therapy) currently lack proof of benefit in humans and carry safety concerns (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__015).

citations.relevant_quote: limited translatability of results obtained in model organisms, additionally confined by the need for extremely time-consuming clinical studies in the ostensible absence of robust bio- markers

response.answer: In the provided sources, exercise activates the energy sensor AMPK; this activation is a proximal response to energetic stress during exercise (AMPK activation). Activated AMPK then promotes SIRT1 activity (via changes in NAD+/NADH), and SIRT1 deacetylates and thereby activates the transcriptional coactivator PGC-1α. Exercise also directly increases PGC-1α expression in skeletal muscle. Active PGC-1α coactivates transcription factors (NRF1, TFAM) to drive mitochondrial biogenesis and improves mitochondrial quality control by stimulating mitophagy and reducing ROS. AMPK additionally regulates mitochondrial dynamics and exercise-induced mitophagy (e.g., mediating mitochondrial fission and phosphorylating Ulk1 to target mitochondria to lysosomes). Together, these linked responses improve mitochondrial content, quality, and oxidative metabolism in muscle following exercise.

response.answer: Summary: In this mouse study, endurance exercise increased basal autophagic/mitophagy flux in skeletal muscle, and that autophagy was required for the exercise-induced increases in mitochondrial biogenesis markers. Acute pharmacological inhibition of autophagy (colchicine) abolished the exercise-induced increases in PGC‑1α and mitochondrial marker proteins, indicating that mitophagy and mitochondrial biogenesis are tightly coupled during adaptation to endurance training (ju_2016, ju_2016__abstract__000; ju_2016, ju_2016__results__002). Additional in-study and transgenic evidence links defective autophagy to reduced exercise benefits and impaired mitochondrial function, supporting a necessary role for autophagy in exercise-driven mitochondrial adaptation (ju_2016, ju_2016__introduction__001; ju_2016, ju_2016__results__003). The study also reports that PINK1/Parkin protein levels were unchanged while Bnip3 was implicated in exercise-induced mitophagy, and that short-term inhibition of autophagy is sufficient to reverse the effects of 8 weeks of training, implying rapid mitochondrial turnover and transcriptional regulation (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__001; ju_2016, ju_2016__results__002).

citations.relevant_quote: The autophagic flux assay demonstrated that swimming training resulted in an increase in the autophagic flux (*100 % increase in LC3-II) in mouse skeletal muscle.

increased mitochondrial biogenesis markers were observed when autophagy was activated by exercise training, while exercise training-induced mitochondrial biogenesis was abolished when mitophagy was inhibited with colchicine treatment.

mice with deficient/defective autophagy (e.g., Becn1?/-, Atg6?/-, and Atg7-/-) have been shown to result in an attenuation of exercise-induced metabolic benefits, decreased in mitochondrial function and exercise performance
the present study demonstrated that 8-week swimming exercise training increases the basal autophagy flux and expression of the autophagy/mitophagy-related genes in mouse skeletal muscle.
The present study showed that the protein levels of PINK1 and Parkin were unchanged by exercise training as well as colchicine treatment.
a short-term inhibition of autophagy is sufficient to reverse/abolish the effects of 8 weeks of exercise training and this effect is transcriptionally regulated.

The dependence on autophagy was shown using short-term pharmacological inhibition (colchicine) in trained mice; results may differ with other models or chronic genetic loss of autophagy (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__002).

The study reports PINK1/Parkin were unchanged and highlights Bnip3 involvement, but regulatory kinases/phosphatases for Bnip3 are stated as not known in the text (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__001; ju_2016, ju_2016__results__002).

response.answer:
The Cell 2023 review frames several key, interrelated criteria for evaluating biomarkers of aging.  Summarized succinctly, the principal criteria are:

- Age-sensitivity and outcome prediction: the biomarker should (1) correlate with multiple age-sensitive features after adjusting for chronological age and (2) be a good predictor of all-cause mortality (i.e., predict aging-associated outcomes) (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__001).

- Responsiveness (response criteria): the biomarker should be responsive to both accelerated and decelerated aging and indicate biological reactions to interventions or exposures (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__003) (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__003).

- Mechanistic grounding: the biomarker should reflect underlying cellular and molecular processes (the ‘‘hallmarks/pillars’’ of aging) so it links to biology rather than only statistical correlates (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002).

- Generalizability: the biomarker should function across relevant settings (tissues, species, and human populations) or at least the limits of its applicability should be understood (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002).

- Integrative/multisystem performance: composite, multisystem biomarkers are preferred because they are more robust and better correlate with other aging features than single measures (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__001).

- Distinction of progress versus pace: evaluators should distinguish biomarkers that estimate the progress of aging (biological age / AgeDev) from those that measure the pace or rate of aging (speedometer vs. odometer roles); both can be complementary (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__002) (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002).

- Clinical validation / surrogate endpoint evidence: for use as surrogate endpoints, biomarker changes must be linked to demonstrable clinical benefits in humans (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001).

- Practical considerations: appropriate sample/tissue choice and feasibility (including measurement cost) are important for real-world application and scalability (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__002) (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__004).

citations.relevant_quote: a biomarker of aging should (1) correlate with multiple age-sensitive features after adjusting for chronological age and (2) be a good predictor of all-cause mortality.
Response criteria Generally, response criteria posit that a biomarker of aging should be responsive to both accelerated and decelerated aging.
A response biomarker indicates the biological reaction of an individual to an exposure or intervention.
a valid biomarker of aging should reflect these underlying cellular and molecular processes.
Generalizability broadly refers to the ability of biomarkers to function across different applications.
composite multisystem biomarkers are more robust and show a stronger correlation with other features of aging than single biomarkers of aging.
An important conceptual distinction needs to be made between biomarkers of biological age and biomarkers of the rate of aging.
Validation of a biomarker as a surrogate endpoint requires clinical evidence that a change in the surrogate endpoint predicts a specific clinical benefit.
the biological sample used for measuring aging is critical.
To implement biomarkers of aging in large-scale settings... the cost of measurement must be relatively low.

response.answer:
Each mechanism is supported by human and animal data in the provided sources.

Details and supporting citations:
- Preservation of muscle mass and function with lifelong aerobic training is observed in humans: “lifelong aerobic exercise is also effective at maintaining skeletal muscle mass and function with age.” (s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__conclusion__000).

- Mitochondria and proteostasis: endurance/aerobic exercise upregulates mitochondrial adaptations (biogenesis and quality) and proteostatic mechanisms; enhanced mitophagy can drive muscle hypertrophy in aged animals. For example, older physically active subjects “have similar mitochondrial function to young physically active individuals” (s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__introduction__002), “Exercise training, particularly endurance exercise, induced mitochondrial biogenesis in skeletal muscle” (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__007), and “Enhancement of mitochondrial protein turnover by upregulation of mitophagy produces muscle hypertrophy in aged mice” (s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__introduction__003).

- Motor units / NMJ: endurance training improves MU and NMJ function, which helps prevent age-related losses in muscle size and function: “endurance exercise training improves MU and NMJ function, implicating endurance exercise for prevention and as treatment of age-related losses in muscle function and size.” (s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__introduction__001).

- Muscle growth / protein-turnover signaling: endurance exercise alters regulators of muscle mass—examples in the literature show exercise lowers inhibitory myostatin and reduces proteolytic ubiquitin ligases: “Both endurance exercise and resistance exercise decrease muscle and plasma levels of myostatin” and “proteolytic ubiquitin ligases, like MuRF-1 and Atrogin-1... can be reduced by exercise training,” which can limit wasting and support maintenance of mass (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__006).

- Vascular and lipid environment: endurance training promotes angiogenesis to improve nutrient/gas delivery (“improved exercise capacity by endurance exercise training is also associated with angiogenesis, an expansion of the capillary network... to improve gas and nutrient delivery.”) and “Aerobic exercise also minimizes age-related accumulation of intermuscular lipids,” both of which support healthier muscle tissue (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__007; s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__introduction__000).

- Human evidence concordant with these mechanisms: cross-sectional studies of lifelong exercisers (masters athletes) report preserved quadriceps lean mass across age groups: “there were no differences in quadriceps muscle lean mass across the age groups” (s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__introduction__000).

Caveat: the review authors note that “additional research is still needed on how aerobic exercise... preserves muscle mass, and function with age” (s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__conclusion__000).

[Source: f1000_2016 | Section: introduction | Pages: 3-4]

response.answer:
Short answer — shared targets, different delivery and evidence. All three approaches converge on nutrient‑sensing pathways (mTOR/TOR, insulin/IGF signaling, AMPK) but differ in how they engage them and in the strength of longevity evidence across organisms and humans.

Mechanisms — caloric restriction (CR): CR down‑regulates insulin/IGF and TOR pathways and activates energy sensors that inhibit mTOR and promote cellular cleanup (autophagy). CR “activates AMP‑activated protein kinase (AMPK) … which then inhibits mTORC1” and CR involves “down‑regulation of insulin and insulin‑like signalling (IIS), as well as of the amino signalling target of rapamycin (TOR)”. (nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__results__000) (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__000).

Mechanisms — intermittent fasting (IF): IF uses cyclic fasting/feeding to improve insulin sensitivity and to trigger stress‑response pathways (for example heat shock proteins and sirtuins) and autophagy more intermittently; it has been reported to give short‑term improvements in body composition and cardiovascular markers. The review states that IF “demonstrates short‑term improvements in body composition, cardiovascular markers, and cardiovascular risk scores,” and that IF’s cyclic periods may “upregulat[e] protective pathways such as heat shock proteins and sirtuins.” (nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__results__001) (nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__results__001).


Evidence for longevity — model organisms: CR is the most reproducible intervention for increasing healthy lifespan across model organisms from yeast to primates: “Caloric restriction is the most effective and reproducible dietary intervention known to regulate aging and increase the healthy lifespan in various model organisms.” Intermittent and periodic fasting can also increase lifespan in some models even without a net calorie reduction: “Both intermittent and periodic fasting can increase lifespan, even when there is little or no overall decrease in calorie intake.” (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__abstract__000) (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__002).

Evidence for longevity — humans and clinical trials: Human data are more limited and heterogeneous. A controlled trial (CALERIE) found that two years of 25% CR is feasible and yields health benefits such as reduced inflammatory markers and cardiometabolic risk factors, though CR was associated with reduced bone mineral density. At the same time, reviews note that “no clear evidence of longevity benefits of bona fide caloric restriction in humans currently exists,” and that variability in study design, participant characteristics, and diet protocols complicates interpretation. (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__introduction__001) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__014) (nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__results__002).

The review concludes that diet composition and periodic interventions can achieve some effects “without an overall reduction in calorie intake.” However, translation to clear human longevity benefits remains unresolved due to heterogeneous results, genetic and sex differences, and differing protocols. (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__conclusion__000) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__014) (nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__results__002).

Generalizability of biomarkers between different ll 3766 Cell 186, August 31, 2023 Perspective tissues and between in vivo and in vitro settings ma

response.answer:
Summary — high-level: Both papers present structured frameworks for evaluating aging biomarkers and emphasize the need for rigorous validation, mechanistic relevance, and generalizability. They differ in emphasis: Moqri et al. (Cell 2023) formalize concepts like AgeDev and the odometer vs speedometer distinction and stress multisystem, cross-species, and mechanistic criteria; Furrer & Handschin (Physiol Rev 2025) place stronger emphasis on the current limitations of molecular "clocks," the readiness and central role of physiological/functional biomarkers, and pragmatic considerations (feasibility, invasiveness, cost) for benchmarking molecular measures.

Agreements
- Both present a formal framework for classifying and assessing biomarkers of aging (e.g., predictive/prognostic/response uses) and call for standardized evaluation (Cell; Physiol Rev) (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__000) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008).
- Both require mechanistic grounding and cross-context generalizability (mechanistic criteria, validation across species/populations) (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008).
- Both caution that molecular clocks can be affected by technical, preanalytical, or physiological confounders and therefore need longitudinal and standardized validation (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__001) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__007).
- Both endorse composite/multisystem approaches as more robust than single measures (Cell emphasizes integrative biomarkers; Physiol Rev highlights combining proteome/metabolome and benchmarking against physiological measures) (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__001) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__009).

Key differences / emphases
- Conceptual framing: Moqri et al. formalize AgeDev and explicitly distinguish biomarkers of the progress of aging (biological age / "odometer") from biomarkers of the rate of aging ("speedometer") as complementary concepts (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002).  Furrer & Handschin do not foreground that specific odometer/speedometer terminology in the provided excerpts but focus on broader assessment/validation dimensions (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008).
- Physiological vs molecular priority: Furrer & Handschin argue physiological/functional biomarkers (cardiorespiratory fitness, muscle mass/strength, frailty) are "ready for prime time," underappreciated, and should be used to benchmark molecular biomarkers; they stress practical criteria (feasibility, invasiveness, cost) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__010) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__009). Moqri et al. strongly promote multisystem/composite molecular and omic biomarkers and cross-species translatability but give more conceptual detail about how to evaluate biomarker types (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__001) (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__000).
- Practical cautions and current state: Furrer & Handschin explicitly emphasize current technical and context limitations of molecular clocks (circadian effects, tissue differences) and urge caution until longitudinal validation in large cohorts is available (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__007) (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__008). Moqri et al. likewise note challenges of data-driven models (risk of picking correlates or study-specific features) and call for mechanistic interpretability, but they frame these within a broader methodological and regulatory classification effort (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__001) (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__000).

Net takeaway: The two frameworks are complementary. Moqri et al. provide a conceptual and methodological taxonomy (including AgeDev and pace vs progress distinctions) and stress mechanistic and cross-species criteria; Furrer & Handschin apply a pragmatic lens that elevates physiological/functional measures as immediate benchmarks while documenting concrete technical pitfalls and validation needs for molecular clocks. Each paper thus highlights different priorities in moving biomarkers toward clinical and research utility.

Thus, at the moment, all of these molecular clocks will have to be used with caution, awaiting validation in longitudinal human studies in large cohorts (549, 550).

response.answer:
Across the corpus, exercise-related studies converge on a small set of recurring molecular themes by which exercise alters mitochondrial function.  First, exercise activates canonical mitochondrial biogenesis programs centered on PGC-1α (PGC-1 alpha is repeatedly identified as a nodal regulator and exercise stimulates its transcription), with p38 MAPK implicated as an upstream activator of PGC-1α (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__024; mol_bio_rep_2025, mol_bio_rep_2025__abstract__010). Second, cellular energy sensing via AMPK—including a mitochondria-localized AMPK pool—links energetic stress to mitophagy and mitochondrial quality control (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__024). Third, autophagy/mitophagy pathways are repeatedly reported as essential for exercise-induced mitochondrial remodeling and functional adaptation (exercise reestablishes autophagic flux and mitochondrial quality control; autophagy is required for exercise training–induced skeletal muscle adaptation), with Parkin-mediated mitophagy implicated in exercise cardioprotection (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__025; biology_2019, biology_2019__body__032; cells_2022, cells_2022__body__026). Fourth, studies emphasize mitochondrial proteostasis and turnover as a target of endurance training: exercise produces distinct remodeling of mitochondrial proteostasis markers and enhancement of mitochondrial protein turnover via mitophagy can produce hypertrophy in aged muscle (s2468867319, s2468867319_2019__introduction__004; s2468867319, s2468867319_2019__introduction__003). Fifth, exercise upregulates antioxidant and redox-related responses (for example, resistance exercise decreases oxidative DNA damage and increases cytochrome oxidase activity; mitochondrial quality correlates with aerobic fitness) that accompany mitochondrial functional improvements (biology_2019, biology_2019__body__031; biology_2019, biology_2019__body__030). Finally, transcriptional regulators tied to lysosomal/autophagic control (TFEB) are induced by exercise in a PGC-1α–dependent manner, linking biogenesis and degradation pathways (biology_2019, biology_2019__body__032).

Taken together, the corpus frames exercise-induced mitochondrial adaptation as an integrated program: upstream signaling (p38 MAPK, AMPK) activates biogenesis (PGC-1α) while concurrently engaging quality-control pathways (autophagy/mitophagy, Parkin) and proteostatic and antioxidant responses, producing improvements in mitochondrial quantity and quality with exercise training (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__024; cells_2022, cells_2022__body__025; biology_2019, biology_2019__body__030).

Mitochondria express enhanced quality as well as quantity in association with aerobic fitness across recreationally active individuals up to elite athletes.

response.evidence_quality: Multiple review articles and empirical studies in the corpus consistently report overlapping signaling nodes (PGC-1α, AMPK, p38 MAPK), quality-control mechanisms (autophagy/mitophagy, Parkin), proteostasis remodeling, and antioxidant responses.
caveats: The corpus notes that the impact of long-term endurance exercise on proteostatic mechanisms is underexplored (s2468867319, s2468867319_2019__introduction__004).

Authors caution that acute snapshots of responses can be misleading for assessing chronic adaptations, implying differences across time courses and study designs (s2468867319, s2468867319_2019__introduction__004).

response.answer: Collectively, these studies indicate that the longevity advantage is greatest when sleep, physical activity, and diet are reasonably optimal together rather than treated in isolation. Stamatakis et al. report an “optimal” SPAN combination of moderate sleep (≈7.2–8.0 h/day), high MVPA, and higher diet quality (DQS ~57.5–72.5) linked with much lower mortality, and they estimate that very small concurrent improvements (e.g., +15 min sleep, +1.6 min MVPA, +5 DQS) are associated with a meaningful (~10%) lower mortality risk (i.e., modest combined changes can matter). The Lancet (Koemel et al.) analysis similarly finds that modest joint gains (for example +5 min sleep, +1.9 min MVPA, +5 DQS) are associated with about one additional year of lifespan and that optimal SPAN combinations can be linked to up to nearly a decade of additional lifespan/healthspan. Both papers emphasise a synergistic pattern in which diet’s benefits are most apparent when combined with more optimal sleep and activity. An earlier NHANES clustering analysis also found that distinct combined SPAN profiles were associated with mortality, supporting the idea that combinations of behaviours (not single behaviours alone) matter for longevity.

A study of just over 1000 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey participants revealed the effects of different combinations of the SPAN exposures with all-cause mortality via model-based clustering analysis

response.evidence_quality: Good — findings come from large prospective cohorts using device-based sleep and activity measures and a comprehensive diet score; results are internally consistent across analyses.
caveats: The papers frame some estimates as "theoretical" and interpret associations under an "assuming causal relationships" qualifier, i.e., these are observational associations rather than randomized causal proofs (as stated in the source texts).

response.answer:
Across the provided corpus the most commonly acknowledged methodological limitations in human longevity research are:

- Limited translatability from model organisms: findings in canonical experimental models may not be directly extrapolatable or feasible in humans (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__003).

- Long timeframes and need for large longitudinal studies: human trials and validation require extremely time‑consuming clinical studies (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__abstract__000).

- Lack of consensus and robustness of molecular “clocks”: no consensus methodology for clocks as standard biomarkers, and many clocks lack physiological/functional validation (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006).

- High technical variability and measurement noise: significant deviations between technical replicates and large transcriptional/metabolomic noise limit reproducibility (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__007; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006).

- Tissue heterogeneity and sampling effects (including circadian timing): age‑dependent measures differ between organs, cell types, spatial locations, and time of sampling (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__007).

- Environmental and laboratory artifacts and socioeconomic confounders: standardized lab conditions and human socioeconomic/environmental differences can introduce artifacts or dominate effects on health outcomes (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__003; furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__002).

- Data quality and recordkeeping issues in special cohorts (e.g., Blue Zones): poor recordkeeping and classification challenge interpretation of such population findings (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__001).

- Cost and feasibility limits for advanced omics/assays: some promising proteomic/metabolomic approaches are currently limited by prohibitive costs (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006).

- Measurement-specific methodological variation (example: telomere analysis): telomere assays can show considerable variation across individuals, tissues, and sampling sites (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__006).

- Confounding interactions with lifestyle interventions: experimental/drug interventions can interact with proven lifestyle effects (e.g., exercise), complicating interpretation (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__004).

These points summarize the recurring methodological concerns raised across the corpus and are supported by the cited excerpts below.

response.answer:
Short answer: Yes, there is evidence—primarily from animal studies—that caloric restriction (CR) can be harmful or reduce lifespan in some genetic backgrounds and sexes, and can cause health problems; human evidence about effects on longevity is unclear.

Evidence from animals: In genetically diverse mouse strains, CR has produced suboptimal health outcomes (loss of lean mass, compromised immune function, disrupted erythroid populations) and a sexually dimorphic response that "can lead to diametrically opposite effects of caloric restriction on lifespan in males and females" (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__014). Experimental reviews also note that CR "results in both beneficial and detrimental effects" (f1000_2016, f1000_2016__abstract__000).

Human evidence: The human picture is mixed—short-term trials show some biomarker benefits, for example the CALERIE trial where "caloric restriction led to slower biological aging compared to the ad libitum approach" (nutrients_2024, nutrients_2024__methods__000), but reviewers state that "no clear evidence of longevity benefits of bona fide caloric restriction in humans currently exists" (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__014). Clinical concerns reported include psychological and physiological adverse effects such as "frailty, reduced cognitive performance, impaired wound healing, and immune function" (furrer_handschin_2025, furrer_handschin_2025__results__014).

Bottom line: Animal data demonstrate that CR can sometimes be harmful to lifespan depending on strain and sex; human long-term effects on lifespan remain unproven and potential adverse effects have been reported.

results in both beneficial and detrimental effects.

Finally, psychological factors of prolonged caloric restriction, e.g., on mood, depression or aggression, and reported adverse effects, e.g., frailty, reduced cognitive performance, impaired wound healing, and immune function, will have to be dealt with

response.evidence_quality: moderate
caveats: Evidence for harm is strongest in animal (rodent and other model) studies and is influenced by genetic background and sex.
Human data do not show clear longevity harm but are limited; short-term trials report biomarker benefits while reviewers note lack of long-term mortality evidence.

response.answer: The provided mouse data indicate autophagy is permissive and regulatory for exercise-induced mitochondrial biogenesis in skeletal muscle. Swimming training increased basal autophagic flux (LC3-II) in muscle (ju_2016, ju_2016__abstract__000). When autophagy/mitophagy was active, mitochondrial biogenesis markers (PGC-1α, SDH, COX IV) increased, but a short-term pharmacologic inhibition of autophagy (colchicine) abolished those exercise-induced increases (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__002; ju_2016, ju_2016__abstract__000). The authors state that autophagy “serves as an important regulator in mitochondrial biogenesis” and that “mitophagy and mitochondrial biogenesis are tightly coupled,” so a coordinated balance between degradation and synthesis is required for mitochondrial adaptation to endurance exercise (ju_2016, ju_2016__results__003). Supporting evidence from autophagy-deficient mice shows loss of autophagy attenuates exercise-induced mitochondrial and performance benefits (ju_2016, ju_2016__introduction__001).

citations.relevant_quote: The autophagic flux assay demonstrated that swimming training resulted in an increase in the autophagic flux (*100 % increase in LC3-II) in mouse skeletal muscle.

This assay demonstrated that increased mitochondrial biogenesis markers were observed when autophagy was activated by exercise training, while exercise training-induced mitochondrial biogenesis was abolished when mitophagy was inhibited with colchicine treatment (Fig. 5).
This and the present study show that autophagy serves as an important regulator in mitochondrial biogenesis during muscle adaptation in response to exercise training.

mice with deficient/defective autophagy (e.g., Becn1?/-, Atg6?/-, and Atg7-/-) have been shown to result in an attenuation of exercise-induced metabolic benefits, decreased in mitochondrial function and exercise performance [14–17].

response.evidence_quality: In vivo experimental mouse data using an 8-week swimming training protocol, an autophagic flux assay, short-term pharmacologic inhibition (colchicine), and supportive genetic-model observations.
caveats: Findings are from mouse skeletal muscle experiments (swimming training and short-term colchicine treatment) rather than human studies (ju_2016, ju_2016__abstract__000; ju_2016, ju_2016__results__002).

response.answer:
In the excerpts provided, exercise activates AMPK, which then engages SIRT1 and PGC-1α in a coordinated response that improves mitochondrial function and quality control. Specifically: 

- Exercise activates AMPK (exercise is reported as a crucial stimulus for AMPK activation) and under low-energy conditions AMPK is activated by an increased AMP/ATP ratio; AMPK activation can stimulate SIRT1 by enhancing the NAD+/NADH ratio (linking energy sensing to SIRT1 activation) (mol_bio_rep_2025, mol_bio_rep_2025__abstract__000) (mol_bio_rep_2025, mol_bio_rep_2025__abstract__001). 

- Physical exercise raises SIRT1 levels in tissues (shown in the swimming study) and SIRT1 deacetylates PGC-1α, increasing PGC-1α activity and promoting expression of genes that regulate mitochondrial function (mol_bio_rep_2025, mol_bio_rep_2025__abstract__002) (mol_bio_rep_2025, mol_bio_rep_2025__abstract__003). 



- AMPK has direct roles in mitochondrial remodeling during energetic stress and exercise: it mediates mitochondrial fission and its phosphorylation of Ulk1 is required for targeting mitochondria to lysosomes in exercise-induced mitophagy; exercise also reestablishes autophagic flux and mitochondrial quality control in stressed hearts (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__035) (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__025). 

Together, these steps describe an exercise-responsive AMPK → SIRT1 → PGC-1α axis that promotes mitochondrial biogenesis, autophagy/mitophagy, improved oxidative metabolism, and resilience to oxidative stress in the provided excerpts (mol_bio_rep_2025, mol_bio_rep_2025__abstract__003).

caveats: The excerpts describe the pathway and experimental observations but do not provide quantitative details (timing, exercise intensity, tissue-specific kinetics) or mechanistic stoichiometry in these snippets.

response.answer:
The review defines several key evaluation criteria for aging biomarkers. Briefly these are:

- Age-sensitivity: the biomarker should (1) correlate with multiple age-sensitive features after adjusting for chronological age and (2) predict all-cause mortality (i.e., relate to AgeDev and outcomes). (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__001)

- Responsiveness (response criteria): the biomarker should be responsive to both accelerated and decelerated aging and to interventions that alter aging. (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__003)

- Mechanistic relevance: a valid biomarker should reflect underlying cellular and molecular processes (the hallmarks/pillars) of aging. (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002)

- Generalizability: biomarkers should function across tissues, settings, species or human populations; proposed biomarkers must be validated across countries, sexes, ethnicities, and other demographic factors. (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__002) (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__003)

- Integrative/composite performance: multisystem or composite biomarkers are generally more robust and correlate better with other aging features than single biomarkers. (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__001)

- Distinction of purpose — progress versus pace: distinguish biomarkers that estimate total accumulated biological aging (biological age / "odometer") from those that estimate current rate of aging ("speedometer"); both have complementary value. (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__002)

- Sample/tissue considerations: the biological sample and cell/tissue specificity matter because some biomarkers mainly reflect particular systems (e.g., blood) and cell-type- or tissue-specific biomarkers may be needed. (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__002)

- Validation and surrogate-endpoint requirements: biomarkers require analytical and clinical validation to establish usefulness; surrogate endpoint biomarkers, after appropriate validation, may substitute for clinical outcomes in trials but demand strong clinical evidence. (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001) (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__004)

These criteria are presented as complementary; the review emphasizes using evaluated geroprotectors and cross-cohort validation to benchmark biomarkers. (cell_2023, cell_2023__results__004) (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001)

citations.relevant_quote: Validity criteria may be further expanded into two related criteria: a biomarker of aging should (1) correlate with multiple age-sensitive features after adjusting for chronological age and (2) be a good predictor of all-cause mortality.
Response criteria Generally, response criteria posit that a biomarker of aging should be responsive to both accelerated and decelerated aging.
Accordingly, a valid biomarker of aging should reflect these underlying cellular and molecular processes.
Generalizability broadly refers to the ability of biomarkers to function across different applications.
It is thus critical to validate proposed biomarkers across countries, sexes, ethnicities, and other demographic factors.
Unsprisingly, composite multisystem biomarkers are more robust and show a stronger correlation with other features of aging than single biomarkers of aging.
An important conceptual distinction needs to be made between biomarkers of biological age and biomarkers of the rate of aging.
the biological sample used for measuring aging is critical.
Clinical validation seeks to establish whether a biomarker can indeed identify the outcome of interest and determine how useful it is for clinical decision making.

Surrogate endpoint biomarkers After appropriate validation, surrogate endpoint biomarkers may be used in clinical trials as a substitute for a direct measure of how a patient or participant feels, functions, or survives
evaluated geroprotectors can be used to develop and benchmark biomarkers of aging, while evaluated biomarkers of aging may be used to predict or test the response to candidate geroprotectors.
A key step along this road is validation of biomarkers across multiple cohorts of humans.

response.evidence_quality: high
caveats: The review stresses that many biomarkers remain to be clinically validated across cohorts and that no aging biomarkers have yet achieved regulatory approval for clinical use (see cited passages). (cell_2023, cell_2023__methods__001)

response.answer:
Short summary: Long-term aerobic (endurance) exercise preserves skeletal muscle mass and function during aging by maintaining mitochondrial health and proteostasis, supporting neuromuscular function, modulating growth regulators, and promoting local vascular and anabolic adaptations (see citations). 

Key mechanisms (each claim is supported by the cited source):
- Maintains mitochondrial content and quality: endurance training induces mitochondrial biogenesis via upregulation of PGC-1α and improves mitochondrial function, which supports muscle energy production and slows age-related decline (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__007; s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__introduction__000).
- Promotes proteostasis and mitophagy: endurance exercise stimulates proteostatic mechanisms and upregulation of mitophagy, and enhanced mitochondrial protein turnover via mitophagy has been linked to muscle hypertrophy in aged mice (s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__introduction__003).
- Preserves neuromuscular units and NMJ function: endurance training improves motor unit (MU) and neuromuscular junction (NMJ) function, which helps prevent age-related loss of muscle size and function (s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__introduction__001).
- Lowers inhibitory growth signals and supports anabolic signaling: both endurance and resistance exercise decrease muscle and plasma myostatin levels, and exercise-associated anabolic signaling (e.g., Akt–mTOR) is associated with improved muscle protein synthesis (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__006; cells_2022, cells_2022__body__006).
- Improves local muscle perfusion and metabolic support: endurance training is associated with angiogenesis (capillary expansion) in recruited muscles, which aids nutrient and oxygen delivery to support muscle maintenance (cells_2022, cells_2022__body__007).

Overall evidence in the provided context: multiple review articles and experimental studies report that lifelong aerobic exercise is effective at maintaining skeletal muscle mass and function with age (s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__conclusion__000; s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__introduction__000). 

Caveat: The context notes that some molecular mechanisms remain incompletely understood and that additional research is needed to fully define how aerobic exercise preserves muscle mass with age (s2468867319_2019, s2468867319_2019__conclusion__000).

response.answer:
Multiple types of epigenetic biomarkers have been reported to change after dietary and/or exercise interventions. Main categories and examples reported in intervention studies include:

- DNA methylation (DNAm) of specific genes: examples include reductions in ADRB3 methylation after a folate + hazelnut oil diet (8 weeks) (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__004), higher regional DNAm at CPT1A associated with larger triglyceride reductions on a low-fat diet (2 years) (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__003), modulation of LINC00319 DNAm in relation to blood pressure changes on a low-fat diet (2 years) (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__005), and DNAm changes in CD36, CD14, FADS1, and PDK4 after a fish-oil–supplemented weight-loss diet (8 weeks) (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__008).  

- Global/epigenome-wide methylation markers: changes or associations involving LINE-1 and LUMA (TMEM43) have been reported in relation to glycemic or other metabolic changes after lifestyle interventions (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__001; nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__003).  

- microRNA (miRNA) expression: many circulating miRNAs change with diet and/or exercise. Examples in the review include decreases in circulating miR-100 and miR-99a after lifestyle-induced reductions in ectopic fat (18 months) (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__004); a panel of 12 circulating miRs (e.g., miR-106b, let-7c, miR-17, miR-192, miR-22) able to predict fasting glucose changes after a 12-week behavioral intervention (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__003); and intervention-related changes in miR-128-3p, miR-10a-5p, miR-211-5p, miR-21, miR-15, miR-126 and others linked to inflammatory, glycemic, lipid, or adipokine outcomes (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__006; nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__007; nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__002).  

- Changes in epigenetic enzyme expression: interventions combining exercise and dietary supplements have been reported to modulate DNMT mRNA expression in leukocytes, linked to DNAm changes (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__009).  

- Histone modifications are identified as a principal epigenetic signature in the field, although specific intervention examples in this review are less emphasized compared with DNAm and miRNAs (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__000).  

Overall, the review reports numerous gene-specific DNAm changes, global methylation markers (LINE-1/LUMA), altered circulating miRNA profiles, and modulation of DNMT expression in response to various dietary and exercise interventions. The authors also note that many findings require further validation before clinical application (nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__004; nutrients_2023a, nutrients_2023a__body__005).
